descriptor.name: Study description
descriptor.value: Populations from sub-Saharan Africa have the highest levels of genetic diversity. This characteristic, in addition to historical genetic admixture, can lead to complexities in the design of studies assessing the genetic determinants of disease and human variation. However, such studies of populations from sub-Saharan Africa are also likely to provide new opportunities to discover novel disease susceptibility loci and variants and refine gene?disease association signals. We propose to conduct the first whole genome sequencing (4x coverage) association study of cardiometabolic and infectious traits in up to 10,000 study participants from east, west and southern regions of sub- Saharan Africa, complementing existing efforts in Europe (UK10K) and elsewhere. In this initial phase, we anticipate sequencing up to 2,000 participants from our Ugandan cohort (those without GWAS data, with a view to sequencing additional populatin groups in subsequent financial years.
